Categories: Question Answering -> Contextual Question Answering -> Extractive
Definition: In this task, you will be given a short story. One sentence from the story is chosen. Consider the likely emotions and basic human drives of the participants in that sentence. Does any of these states of mind/feelings motivate the participant to do what happens in that sentence? You should write your answer in the form " A >Motivates> B". Try to use phrases and sentences from the story to compose your answer when possible. For the motivation sentence, you must choose a verb from :feel(s), want(s) or like(s). There will always be some motivation in the given story.

Positive Examples.input:
story: Rita loved riding her bike down the trails of the state park. While she was riding, she came across a bear. She immediately hit a side path. She pedaled as fast as she could out of the state park. Rita will now only go on the trails when she is with friends.
 selected sentence: Rita will now only go on the trails when she is with friends.
Positive Examples.output: Rita feel(s) scared >Motivates> Rita will only go on the trails with her friends
Positive Examples.explanation: The story is about Rita being scared in her experience, so the answer is correct.

Positive Examples.input:
story: Today I have been working on the alphabet with my son. He has learned the first three letters. Today we are working on the fourth and fifth letters. He has been a little frustrated, but he keep on trying. By the end of the day he had learned the new letters.
 selected sentence: Today we are working on the fourth and fifth letters.
Positive Examples.output: I want(s) to work >Motivates> I work
Positive Examples.explanation: In this example, it seems the only motivation for the given sentence is the will of the speaker, so the output is correct.

Negative Examples.input:
story: Jeremy wants a dog. His wife says no because they already have a cat. Jeremy gets a dog anyway and keeps it in the back yard. The cat gets out and runs to the back yard, they fear the worst. They hurry to the back yard only to find the cat and dog playing.
 selected sentence: They hurry to the back yard only to find the cat and dog playing.
Negative Examples.output: Jeremy and his wife want(s) to catch the cat >Motivates> They hurry to the back yard to find the cat and dog playing
Negative Examples.explanation: Here the emotion causing Jeremy and his wife to hurry to the back yard is them being scared, so the correct answer would be: They feel(s) fearful >Motivates> They hurry to the back yard to find the cat and dog playing

Negative Examples.input:

 selected sentence: One day she build a really big one.
Negative Examples.output: Susie like(s) building forts so Susie builds a fort
Negative Examples.explanation: The cause is correctly identified, but the answer is not in the correct form. There's no >Motivates> in the answer.
